title: Replicating the Latent Variable Estimates of Personalism, Party Autonomy, and Military Autonomy in Wright 2019
text: first replicate factor analysis paper. Figure @ref(fig:fig-b1) reproduces figure B-1 Wright (2021) supplementary material. Figure B1 appendix: Eigenvalues. factor loadings, closely replicating figures paper. next three plots closely reproduce figure 1 paper, showing extent individual variables load onto first three dimensions autocratic rule identified paper: party (Figure @ref(fig:fig-party)), military (Figure @ref(fig:fig-military)), personal (Figure @ref(fig:fig-personal)). Party dimension autocratic rule. Reproduces top panel Figure 1. Military dimension autocratic rule. Reproduces middle panel Figure 1. Personal dimension autocratic rule. Reproduces bottom panel Figure 1. can use factor scores reproduce figure 2 paper, illustrating three dimensions autocratic rule China (Figure @ref(fig:fig-china)). Three dimensions autocratic rule China. Reproduces figure 2 paper. correlations measures democracy reported Figure 3 paper can produced using democracyData package, available https://github.com/xmarquez/democracyData. Figure @ref(fig:fig-correlations-dem) replicates Figure 3 Wright (2021). Corrleation matrix latent dimensions autocratic structure measures democracy. Replicates Figure 3 paper. Correlations measures personalism military used Weeks (2014) original GWF dataset (Geddes, Wright, Frantz 2014) also reported Wright (2021). package also includes simplified version Weeks dataset (basic regime indices), original GWF data can found democracyData package, also includes political regime data Kailitz (2013). can thus replicate Table 1 paper (@ref(tab:tbl-corrs)).
code: gwf_filtered <- gwf |> select(all_of(all_global_vars)) |> na.omit()  # Ensure selected variables are numeric and handle missing values efa_data <- gwf_filtered |>   select(all_of(all_global_vars)) |>   mutate(across(everything(), as.numeric)) |>   drop_na()  # Scree Plot fa.parallel(efa_data, fa = "fa", main = "Scree Plot for EFA") #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> Warning in cor.smooth(r): Matrix was not positive definite, smoothing was done #> In factor.scores, the correlation matrix is singular, the pseudo inverse is  used #> Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  24  and the number of components =  NA # Run EFA with Promax rotation efa_result <- fa(efa_data, nfactors = 4, rotate = "promax") #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> In smc, smcs < 0 were set to .0 #> Warning in cor.smooth(r): Matrix was not positive definite, smoothing was done #> Warning in fa.stats(r = r, f = f, phi = phi, n.obs = n.obs, np.obs = np.obs, : #> The estimated weights for the factor scores are probably incorrect.  Try a #> different factor score estimation method. #> In factor.scores, the correlation matrix is singular, the pseudo inverse is  used  # View factor loadings print(efa_result$loadings, cutoff = 0.3)  #>  #> Loadings: #>                              MR1    MR2    MR3    MR4    #> partyrbrstmp                  0.433         0.306        #> militrank                            0.878               #> ldrrotation                          0.307               #> milconsult                           0.597               #> milmerit_mil                               -0.588        #> milmerit_pers                               0.579        #> milnotrial                                  0.455        #> plebiscite                                               #> heirclan                                    0.414        #> officepers                                  0.635        #> paramil_pers                                0.553        #> paramil_party                                            #> paramil_fightrebel                                       #> supportparty                  0.966                      #> partyleader                   0.721                      #> localorgzns                   0.920                      #> partymins                     0.824                      #> excomcivn                     0.758                      #> multiethnic                   0.550                      #> monoethnic                                               #> heirparty                     0.549        -0.448        #> heirfamily                   -0.338         0.634        #> legcompetn                                         0.350 #> leaderrelatvs                               0.555        #> leaderciv                           -0.707         0.470 #> leadermil                            0.952               #> leaderrebel                   0.312 -0.308        -0.764 #> heirciv                             -0.525 -0.378        #> cabciv                              -0.504               #> cabmil                               0.590               #> partymilit                    0.476        -0.336        #> ldr_group_priordem                                 0.435 #> ldr_group_domparty                         -0.417        #> ldr_group_military                   0.856               #> ldr_group_insurgency                              -0.696 #> ldr_group_civsucc                                        #> ldr_group_other                                          #> ldr_group_foreign                                        #> ldr_group_hereditary         -0.651 -0.422               #> seizure_coup                         0.773               #> seizure_rebel                       -0.390        -0.685 #> seizure_uprising                                         #> seizure_election                                   0.501 #> seizure_succession                                       #> seizure_family               -0.461                      #> partyhistory_priornosupport                              #> partyhistory_priorwonsupport                             #> partyhistory_insurgent        0.345               -0.583 #> partyhistory_priordem                              0.433 #> partyhistory_noparty         -0.966                      #> partyhistory_priorelection                               #> militparty_allyparty                                     #> militparty_noparty           -0.458  0.512               #> militparty_priorparty                0.311               #> nomilitary                                               #> milethnic_inclusive                        -0.318        #> milethnic_hetero                                         #> milethnic_homo                                           #> sectyapp_party                             -0.482        #> sectyapp_pers                               0.649        #> electldr_priordict                                       #> electldr_priordem                                        #> electldr_notelect                                 -0.352 #> electldr_1candidate                                      #> electldr_1faction                                        #> electldr_multileg                                        #> electldr_multiexec                                       #> legnoms_indirect                                  -0.349 #> legnoms_veto                                             #> legnoms_noveto                                           #> legnoms_priordem                                         #> ldr_exp_highrank                     0.769               #> ldr_exp_lowrank                      0.338               #> ldr_exp_rebel                       -0.323        -0.771 #> ldr_exp_demelect                                   0.454 #> ldr_exp_supportparty                       -0.435        #> ldr_exp_pers_loyal                                       #> ldr_exp_pers_relative                                    #> ldr_exp_rulingfamily         -0.673 -0.441               #> ldr_exp_other                                            #> partyexcom_pers               0.470         0.381        #> partyexcom_faction                                       #> partyexcom_oppose                                        #> createparty                          0.416  0.308        #>  #>                  MR1   MR2   MR3   MR4 #> SS loadings    8.909 8.112 5.771 4.738 #> Proportion Var 0.106 0.097 0.069 0.056 #> Cumulative Var 0.106 0.203 0.271 0.328 # Predict factor scores efa_scores <- factor.scores(efa_data, efa_result)$scores |>   as_tibble() #> Warning in cor.smooth(r): Matrix was not positive definite, smoothing was done  gwf <- gwf |>   bind_cols(efa_scores) |>   rename(party_factor = MR1, military_factor = MR2,           personalism_factor = MR3, other_factor = MR4)  # Visualize Loadings  varnames <- dimnames(efa_result$loadings)[[1]] loadings_df <- efa_result$loadings |>   matrix(84, 4) |>   as_tibble(.name_repair = "unique") |>   set_names(c("MR1", "MR2", "MR3", "MR4")) |>   mutate(Variable = varnames) #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> • `` -> `...2` #> • `` -> `...3` #> • `` -> `...4`  loadings_df |>   pivot_longer(MR1:MR4) |>   filter(name == "MR1") |>   mutate(name = "Party") |>   ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(Variable, value), y = value, label = Variable)) +   geom_point(color = 'blue') +   facet_wrap(~name, scales = "free_x") +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "red") +   scale_x_discrete() +   labs(x = "", y = "Factor 1 loadings") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) loadings_df |>   pivot_longer(MR1:MR4) |>   filter(name == "MR2") |>   mutate(name = "Military") |>   ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(Variable, value), y = value, label = Variable)) +   geom_point(color = 'blue') +   facet_wrap(~name, scales = "free_x") +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "red") +   scale_x_discrete() +   labs(x = "", y = "Factor 2 loadings") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) loadings_df |>   pivot_longer(MR1:MR4) |>   filter(name == "MR3") |>   mutate(name = "Personalism") |>   ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(Variable, value), y = value, label = Variable)) +   geom_point(color = 'blue') +   facet_wrap(~name, scales = "free_x") +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "red") +   scale_x_discrete() +   labs(x = "", y = "Factor 3 loadings") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) gwf |>   select(gwf_country, year, ends_with("_factor")) |>   filter(gwf_country == "China") |>   pivot_longer(party_factor:other_factor) |>   filter(name != "other_factor") |>   mutate(name = case_when(name == "party_factor" ~ "party strength",                           name == "military_factor" ~ "military autonomy",                           name == "personalism_factor" ~ "personalism")) |>   ggplot(aes(x = year, y = value, linetype = fct_relevel(name,"personalism", "military autonomy"),              color = fct_relevel(name,"personalism", "military autonomy"))) +   geom_line() +   labs(y = "Latent dimensions", x = "Year", linetype = "", color = "") +   guides(linetype = guide_legend(position = "bottom"),          color = guide_legend(position = "bottom")) +   facet_wrap(~gwf_country) library(democracyData) dem_scores <- generate_democracy_scores_dataset(c("vdem", "fh", "uds_2014", "polity"), output_format = "wide", verbose = FALSE) #> Warning in download_fh(verbose = verbose, include_territories = TRUE): NAs #> introduced by coercion #> Warning in download_fh(verbose = verbose, include_territories = TRUE): NAs #> introduced by coercion  data <- gwf |>   left_join(dem_scores) #> Warning in left_join(gwf, dem_scores): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`. #> ℹ Row 1 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`. #> ℹ Row 191 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`. #> ℹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship = #>   "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.  data |>   select(v2x_polyarchy, polity2, fh_total_reversed, uds_2014_mean,           gwf_leader_duration, party_factor, military_factor, personalism_factor) |>   corrr::correlate() |>   corrr::rplot(print_cor = TRUE)  +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) gwf_all <- democracyData::gwf_all weeks <- GWFdata::weeks kailitz <- democracyData::kailitz |>   rename_with(\(x) paste0("kailitz_", x), .cols = c(personal:monarchy))  data <- gwf |>    left_join(gwf_all) |>   left_join(weeks) |>   left_join(kailitz)  data |>   select(party_factor:personalism_factor, gwf_party:gwf_personal,           juntajlw_2014_1:personalgeddes_2014_1,           kailitz_personal:kailitz_monarchy) |>   mutate(across(everything(), as.numeric)) |>   corrr::correlate() |>   select(term:personalism_factor) |>   filter(!term %in% c("other_factor", "party_factor", "personalism_factor", "military_factor")) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 2) #> Warning in stats::cor(x = x, y = y, use = use, method = method): the standard #> deviation is zero

title: Replicating the Latent Variable Estimates of Personalism, Party Autonomy, and Military Autonomy in Wright 2019
text: code closely replicates item-response theory model autocratic rule described section 7 Wright (2021). Note variables used IRT model can selected directly loadings data frame, 11 variables loadings greater 0.3 third factor: can use procedure calculate party military dimensions rule well, using necessary party military vars. index also can used visualize evolution latent dimensions China (Figure @ref(fig:fig-irt)), significantly different simply using factor scores includes standard error different scale. Evolution latent dimensions rule China. Uses IRT model results.
code: # IRT Modeling (2PL model)   ## Define variables for personalism   pers11 <- c("sectyapp_pers", "officepers", "paramil_pers", "milmerit_pers_recoded",                "milnotrial", "partyexcom_pers", "partyrbrstmp", "leaderrelatvs",                "heirfamily", "heirclan", "createparty")    # Fit 2PL IRT model   pers_irt_model <- mirt::mirt(gwf |>                              select(all_of(pers11)),                            model = 1, itemtype = "2PL", SE = TRUE,                           verbose = FALSE)    # Extract factor scores   pers_irt_scores <- mirt::fscores(pers_irt_model, full.scores.SE = TRUE,                                    verbose = FALSE) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("pers_irt_11_", x))      gwf <- gwf |> bind_cols(pers_irt_scores)    pers10 <- pers11[!pers11 %in% "heirclan"]   pers_irt_model_10 <- mirt::mirt(gwf |> select(all_of(pers10)),                               model = 1, itemtype = "2PL", SE = TRUE,                              verbose = FALSE)   pers_irt_scores_10 <- mirt::fscores(pers_irt_model_10, full.scores.SE = TRUE,                                       verbose = FALSE) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("pers_irt_10_", x))      gwf <- gwf |> bind_cols(pers_irt_scores_10)    # Repeat for 8 variables   pers8 <- pers10[!pers10 %in% c("leaderrebel", "heirfamily")]   pers_irt_model_8 <- mirt::mirt(gwf |> select(all_of(pers8)),                              model = 1, itemtype = "2PL",                             verbose = FALSE)   pers_irt_scores_8 <- mirt::fscores(pers_irt_model_8) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("pers_irt_8_", x))      gwf <- gwf |> bind_cols(pers_irt_scores_10) #> New names: #> • `pers_irt_10_F1` -> `pers_irt_10_F1...147` #> • `pers_irt_10_SE_F1` -> `pers_irt_10_SE_F1...148` #> • `pers_irt_10_F1` -> `pers_irt_10_F1...149` #> • `pers_irt_10_SE_F1` -> `pers_irt_10_SE_F1...150`    # Full info IRT model (2PL + GRM for milmerit_pers)   ## Define variables for personalism   pers10_mixed <- pers11[!pers11 %in% c("milmerit_pers_recoded")]    # Specify model: 2PL for binary, GRM for polytomous variables   mixed_model <- 'F1 = 1-10                    milmerit = grsm'    # Fit full IRT model   pers_irt_mixed <- mirt::mirt(gwf |>                              select(all_of(c(pers10_mixed, "milmerit_pers"))),                            model = mixed_model,                           itemtype = "Rasch", SE = TRUE,                           verbose = FALSE) #> Warning in model.elements(model = model$x, itemtype = itemtype, factorNames = #> factorNames, : NAs introduced by coercion #> Warning: Could not invert information matrix; model may not be (empirically) #> identified.      pers_irt_scores_mixed <- mirt::fscores(pers_irt_model_8, full.scores.SE = TRUE) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("pers_irt_11_full_info_", x))    gwf <- gwf |>      bind_cols(pers_irt_scores_mixed) personalism_vars <- loadings_df |>   filter(MR3 > 0.3) |>   pull(Variable)  personalism_vars[personalism_vars == "milmerit_pers"] <- "milmerit_pers_recoded"  personalism_vars[!personalism_vars %in% pers11] #> character(0) party_vars <- loadings_df |>   filter(MR1 > 0.3) |>   pull(Variable)  military_vars <- loadings_df |>   filter(MR2 > 0.3) |>   pull(Variable)  gwf |>    select(all_of(party_vars)) |>   summarise(across(everything(), n_distinct)) #> # A tibble: 1 × 12 #>   partyrbrstmp supportparty partyleader localorgzns partymins excomcivn #>          <int>        <int>       <int>       <int>     <int>     <int> #> 1            2            2           2           3         4         4 #> # ℹ 6 more variables: multiethnic <int>, heirparty <int>, leaderrebel <int>, #> #   partymilit <int>, partyhistory_insurgent <int>, partyexcom_pers <int>  # We need a graded model  party_irt_model <- mirt::mirt(gwf |>                              select(all_of(party_vars)),                            model = 1, itemtype = "graded", SE = TRUE,                           verbose = FALSE)  # Extract factor scores party_irt_scores <- mirt::fscores(party_irt_model, full.scores.SE = TRUE) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("party_irt_11_", x))    gwf <- gwf |> bind_cols(party_irt_scores)  military_irt_model <- mirt::mirt(gwf |>                              select(all_of(military_vars)),                            model = 1, itemtype = "graded", SE = TRUE,                           verbose = FALSE)  # Extract factor scores military_irt_scores <- mirt::fscores(military_irt_model, full.scores.SE = TRUE) |>     as_tibble() |>     rename_with(\(x) paste0("military_irt_11_", x))    gwf <- gwf |> bind_cols(military_irt_scores) gwf |>   select(gwf_country, year, contains("_irt_11")) |>   pivot_longer(     cols = contains("_irt_11"),     names_to = c("variable", ".value"),     names_pattern = "(.*_irt_11|.*_irt_11_full_info)_(F1|SE_F1)"   ) |>   filter(gwf_country == "China") |>   ggplot(aes(x = year, y = F1, color = variable)) +   geom_line() +   geom_pointrange(aes(ymin = F1-SE_F1, ymax = F1 + SE_F1)) +   labs(y = "Personalism dimension", x = "Year", linetype = "", color = "") +   facet_wrap(~gwf_country)

what: Packages the replication data for the book
title: Packages the replication data for the book
text: GWFdata archives data used Wright (2021) Geddes, Wright, Frantz (2018). also includes subset personalism indicators Weeks (2014). primary purpose package replicate IRT model described Wright (2021), based Stata .file archived Political Science Research Methods dataverse. article detailed instructions included website.

title: Packages the replication data for the book
text: can install development version GWFdata GitHub :

title: Packages the replication data for the book
text: data-package. Just type name dataset want. main dataset gwf. Documentation included variables accessed typing ?gwf. package also includes dataset weeks gwf_irt. latter includes replicated factor scores IRT estimates reported Wright (2021).

title: Autocratic Regime Features, Version 1.0 — gwf
text: cowcode Correlates War country code. Countries  changed territory period 1946 2010 following country codes data set: Czechoslovakia (315); East Germany (265); Ethiopia (530); Eritrea (531); Russia Soviet Union (365); South Vietnam (817); South Yemen (680); Vietnam/North Vietnam (816); Yemen/ North Yemen (678); Yugoslavia/Serbia (435). Note regimes either lost (Ethiopia) gained territory (Vietnam/North Vietnam) lifetime regime country code throughout entire regime spell. Users note feature data set merging data sets. year calendar year gwf_country name country gwf_casename country name set years autocratic regime power. autocratic regime defined set formal /informal rules choosing leaders policies; can multiple regimes within autocratic spell. autocratic spell consecutive calendar years autocratic regime ruled country; autocratic spell may interrupted years democracy, foreign occupier, failed state controlled majority territory. gwf_caseid unique identifying number autocratic regime power January 1 consecutive observation years within country. gwf_case_duration counter variable marks number years autocratic regime power, including observation year; duration = 0 calendar year autocratic regime took power; duration = 1 calendar year first calendar year autocratic regime holds power January 1. Duration time includes years autocratic regime held power prior 1946 independent countries. therefore left-censoring data. gwf_case_fail binary indicator variable whether autocratic regime fails (.e., collapses ends) observation year. gwf_leadername name regime leader January 1 observation year. regime leader de facto leader autocratic regime. autocratic regime leaders power less year power January 1 observation year. leaders omitted data set. gwf_leaderid unique identifying number regime leader January 1 observation year. regime leader de facto leader autocratic regime.individual may regime leader one autocratic regime. example, Joaquin Balaguer considered regime leader Trujillo's regime 1962 Trujillo's assassination 1961. Balaguer also regime leader distinct regime 1966 1978. (coded starting 1967 codings based power January 1 observation year.) leader id variable treats leader episode distinct regime leader. , individual can regime leader within lifetime autocratic regime. example, Crown Prince Faisal (became King 1964) considered regime leader Saudi Arabia 1959 1960, well second longer stint 1962 (natural) death 1975. leader id variable treats leader episodes distinct. encourage users utilize unique identifier instead leader names latter contain names shared across regimes different sources spell names differently. gwf_leader_duration counter variable marks number years regime leader power, including observation year; duration = 1 calendar year first calendar year regime leader holds power January 1. Duration time includes years regime leader held power prior 1946 independent countries. gwf_leader_fail binary indicator variable whether regime leader January 1 observation year exits regime leadership position observation year. regime failure events entail leadership failure: 223 observation-years data coded regime failure events; 469 observation years contain leadership failure events. Thus half leadership failures observation years autocratic regime collapse. gwf_case_startdate numeric code calendar date political event constitutes start regime. gwf_case_enddate numeric code calendar date political event constitutes end regime. gwf_case_prior categorical variable indicating regime type prior observed regime-case: democracy: country independent, sovereign country observed autocratic regime took power regime preceded democratic coded Geddes, Wright Frantz (2014). dictatorship_mil: country independent, sovereign country observed autocratic regime took power regime preceded autocratic led military, coded Geddes, Wright Frantz (2014). dictatorship_nonmil: country independent, sovereign country observed autocratic regime took power regime preceded autocratic led military, coded Geddes, Wright Frantz (2014); includes states Ethiopia prior 1889 Nepal prior 1846 ruled prior dynasties. foreign-occupied: country occupied foreign military power observed autocratic regime took power; includes cases U.S. occupations Afghanistan Iraq U.S. invasions, post-WWII regimes created conquering super-powers, including Soviet satellite states East Germany. -independent: country independent, sovereign country observed autocratic regime took power; includes post-colonial/protectorate regimes, post-Soviet regimes, regimes countries secceeded larger countries, Bangladesh Eritrea. warlord: country's territory ruled warlords without central government prior observed autocratic regime. gwf_leader_firstyear first year regime leader power January 1 observation year. variable coded coincide first year leadership spell (accounting left censoring) autocratic leader. example, Hugo Chavez' first year coded 2006 since autocratic regime started 2005, even though first year office 1999 country still democratic. gwf_fail_subsregime Coded 0 regime ended December 31, 2010. Coded 1 regime follows last year regime coded democratic. Democratic defined regime executive achieved power direct competitive election least ten percent total population (equivalent 40 percent adult male population) eligible vote, major parties permitted compete, neither fraud violence determined election outcome; indirect election body least 60 percent elected direct competitive elections (defined way directly elected executives) Provisional governments charged conducting elections part transition democracy coded democratic elections actually take place candidate party elected allowed take office. sometimes takes year. provisional government following rules agreed regard power sharing preparing fair election, lasts January 1 year following creation longer, later ousted group different incumbent group preceded , code democratic (defined ) time governed. Reconvening legislature constituent assembly previously elected competitive election purpose managing transition democracy coded democratic transition carried . Coded 2 regime year following last year regime coded autocratic, , included autocratic data set. Coded 3 regime followed period neither autocratic democratic. include: Periods country government multiple governments, one controls resources state; periods foreign troops occupy country occupying power governs , exercises major influence governed; failures occur country ceases exist incorporated another (e.g., East Germany, South Yemen). gwf_fail_type Coded 0 regime ended December 31, 2010. Coded 1 regime insiders changed rules choosing leaders policies, executive removed elite actors military, ending period time one set formal informal rules remained force. Use code cases regime insiders changed formal informal rules elections held , example, parties participate suffrage extended population, thus changing identity actors influence policy. Examples might include transitions indirect military rule democracy transitions oligarchy democracy. Coded 2 incumbent, party, coalition, candidate supported incumbent, lost election allowed candidate party won take office. Coded 3 regime held competitive election major candidate party supported incumbent ran, means choosing next government, allowed winner election take office. Also use code incumbent group handed power transitional government purpose holding election determine next government – even transitional election ultimately occur – long democratization prevented current incumbent. Coded 4 regime ousted popular uprising. Popular uprising defined widespread, mostly unarmed demonstrations, riots, /strikes. Coded 5 regime overthrown military coup (defined ouster military regime power). Overthrows insurgencies led ex-officers coded insurgencies coups. Handovers military context popular uprisings, military acts facilitator regime change, coded popular uprisings coups. Transitions direct indirect military rule coded coups made military regime power. Coded 6 regime ousted insurgents, revolutionaries, combatants fighting civil war. Insurgency, revolution, civil war defined involving organized armed conflict. Coded 7 regime changed foreign imposition invasion. Coded 8 new leader chosen regular autocratic succession changed formal informal rules defining regime accession power remaining power. regime's formal informal rules changed sufficiently code new regime, appear list cases separate entry. Regular autocratic successions defined : retirement, illness, death original leader replacement someone previously occupied formal position successor, selected retiring leader, chosen group regime insiders party executive committee, high level officers, combination two. Regular autocratic successions also include original leaders leave office term limits succeeded leader chosen retiring leader; group regime insiders party executive committee, high level officers, combination two. Coded 9 regime ends state ceases exist government loses control territory. gwf_fail_violent Coded 0 regime ended December 31, 2010. Coded 1 non-violent, defined involving deaths. Coded 2 deaths occurred transition. numbers available, '' means 1-25. Coded 3 many deaths occurred transition. numbers available, 'many' means 25 less 1000. Coded 4 1000 deaths occurred. (included Fearon & Laitin.) period1 binary indicator five-year period 1951-1955. period2 binary indicator five-year period 1956-1960. period3 binary indicator five-year period 1961-1965. period4 binary indicator five-year period 1966-1970. period5 binary indicator five-year period 1971-1975. period6 binary indicator five-year period 1976-1980. period7) binary indicator five-year period 1981-1985. period8) binary indicator five-year period 1986-1990. period9) binary indicator five-year period 1991-1995. period10) binary indicator five-year period 1996-2000. period11) binary indicator five-year period 2001-2005. period12) binary indicator five-year period 2006-2010. coldwar) binary indicator Cold War period (1946-1989). ld) Log regime-case duration (natural log gwf case duration). NOTE: data set include categorical variable regime type. autocratic regime type one categories typologies group similar autocratic regimes together. regime type indicator time invariant across regime's duration; examples include: military, party, personalist, monarchy. interested using autocratic regime type data consult: Barbara Geddes, Joseph Wright, Erica Frantz. 2014. "Autocratic Breakdown Regime Transitions: New Data Set." Perspectives Politics 12(2): 313-331; data set available

title: Autocratic Regime Features, Version 1.0 — gwf
text: using data model autocratic regime survival, unit analysis autocratic regime, coded variable gwf_casename. unit analysis authoritarian regime survival autocratic spell regime leader spell. See Geddes, Wright Frantz (2014) Wright Bak (2016) discussion differences modeling autocratice regime survival leader survival. Algeria 1962-1992: FLN/military 1992-2010: military rule autocratic spell lasts 1962 2010 right-censored. bullet point lists distinct autocratic regime. Regime failure (gwf_fail) occurs 1992: January 11, 1992 military coup ousted Benjedid. autocratic regime 1992-2010 right-censored failed December 31, 2010. Algeria six autocratic regime leaders period, three first regime (Ben Bella, Boumediene, Benjedid) three second regime (Nezzar, Zeroual, Bouteflika). Chile 1973-1989: military junta rules Pinochet autocratic spell lasts 1973 1989; right-censored. bullet point lists one autocratic regime. Regime failure (gwf fail) autocratic spell failure occur 1989. one regime failure (gwf_fail) event occurs end autocratic spell:   December 14, 1989 election leads democracy following year. one regime leader (gwf_leadername) period: Pinochet. Congo/DRC/Zaire 1960-1997: Mobutu regime 1997-2010: Kabila (father son) regime autocratic spell lasts 1960 2010 right-censored. bullet points lists distinct autocratic regime. Regime failure occurs 1997. one regime failure event occurs autocratic spell: May 17, 1997 Laurent Kabila's forces take Kinshasa. autocratic regime 1997-2010 right-censored failed December 31, 2010. three regime leaders autocratic spell, one first regime (Mobutu) two second (Laurent Kabila Joseph Kabila). Thailand 1944-1947: Pridi regime 1947-1957: Phibun regime 1957-1973: Sarit, Thanom military 1976-1988: Prem Tinsulanonda military 1991-1992: military junta 2006-2007: military junta six autocratic regimes four autocratic spells; none right-censored. bullet point lists distinct autocratic regime. first three autocratic regimes (1944-1947, 1947-1957, 1957-1973) ruled consecutively, uninterrupted non-autocratic regime, thus constitute one autocratic spell: 1944-1973. three autocratic regimes (1976-1988, 1991-1992, 2006-2007) ended democracy thus constitute separate autocratic spells. nine autocratic regime leaders sample period: one first regime (Pridi); one second (Luang Phibun Songkhram); two third (Sarit Thanom); three fourth (Sangad Chalayu, Kriangsak, Prem Tinsulanonda); one fifth (Suchinda Kraprayoon); one sixth (Sonthi).

title: Autocratic Regime Features, Version 1.0 — gwf
text: Military attributes five ways data code military attributes, summarized Table 1. Note different variables pertain specifically regime leader's career prior assuming office, others refer group put leader power type event regime seized power. Table 1: Military attributes first variable Table 1 identifies whether regime leader member military security service prior assuming office; , leader civilian rebel leader prior assuming office. derived using leaderciv variable raw data set referred leadermil codebook cleaned data. variable therefore similar Cheibub, Gandhi Vreeland (2010) coding military regimes, relies Banks data codes civilian-military distinction leader prior assuming office. second variable identifies military officer rank leader member military prior assuming power. militrank raw data, code book, cleaned data. two leaders data set coded members military prior assuming office ranking officers (Najibullah Afghanistan Sargsian Armenia); security officials formal members military coded military rank. third variable identifies group put regime leader office. derived leaderrole variable raw data; referred ldr_military codebook cleaned data. value 1 variable mean leaders placed power military necessarily members military /military officers five years prior assuming office. example, code Abdelaziz Bouteflika Algeria Francois Duvalier Haiti placed power military even though members military five years prior assuming office. Similarly, members military (five years prior assuming office) may put leader position groups military. example, Raul Castro, high-ranking Cuban military officer prior assuming office, put leadership position family. Empirically, however, likely put office military members military, particularly officers. fourth variable related military regime leader's important career experience, likely developed useful support network. derived ldrexp variable raw data referred ldrexp_highrank ldrexp_lowrank codebook clean data. , leaders whose prior experience based military members military prior assuming office. However, members military prior assuming office, Anastasio Somoza Debayle Raul Castro, coded important prior career experience military. Instead, support network identified family. Finally, data include variable codes type regime seizure event, regime obtained power. derived seizure variable raw data referred seizure_coup codebook cleaned data. Note variable time-invariant across leaders regime. leaders military members prior assuming power occupy leadership position regimes grabbed power via coup, regimes born coups put members military leadership position. example, third leader Algerian military regime, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, put charge regime came power 1992 coup. Conversely, members military (.e., individuals civilians rebel leaders) given leadership positions regimes seized power methods coup, Joseph Kabila. regimes data set coded professionalized, domestically-controlled military, listed Table 2. regime can without professional domestic military regime control number reasons, common following. foreign power either provides security (e.g., Senegal provided security Gambia late 1980s) controls military (e.g., Eastern European countries WWII Central Asian Republics shortly independence former Soviet Union). latter situation, collapsing empire gives way independent countries, closely related instances observing regime-led military: initial post-independence years African countries (e.g., Botswana, Congo-Brazzaville, Ghana, Guinea, Zambia). Finally, Costa Rica military Honduras professional military 1948 (Dodd 2005, 55-56). Afghanistan Taliban rule also coded professional military organization Taliban transform informally organized insurgent armed forces formal military institution seizing power. Table 2: Regimes domestic professional military regime coded professional military, military-related variables coded particular military feature. example, ethnicity military coded 0 variables measuring concept (milethnic_dom, milethnic_hetero, milethnic_homo). regime professional military, necessarily mean regime paramilitary group (paramil_party, paramil_pers, paramil_fightrebel); preclude leader consolidating power security apparatus (milmerit_pers, milnotrial, sectyapp_pers). example, UAE regime-led military 1985, promotion security apparatus still based personal loyalty leader prior 1985 (Cordesman 1997, 297). handful regime leaders (e.g., Banda Malawi, M'Ba Gabon, Zayid UAE) took personal control security apparatus (sectyapp_pers) created new paramilitary (paramil_pers) loyal (e.g., Tombalbaye Chad, Karimov Uzbekistan) prior regime building army replacing foreign officers national ones. Finally, even foreign power direct control military, regime may still military officers present cabinet (e.g., East Germany Poland early 1950s). regime can coded support party : ) regime come power support pre-existing party regime yet create new support party; b) regime disbands (closes ) existing regime support party. regime support party, variables coded party features regime logically true. example, support party rubber-stamp party (partyrbrstmp); party control military (partymilit); cabinet contain members party (partymins); regime leader party leader (partyleader); heir selected party (heirparty). However, coding data allow possibility regime can leader whose main prior experience member dominant political party (ldrexp_supportparty), leader whose initial base support put power dominant party (ldr_domparty), leader selected election. Since variables pertain leader can coded positively even regime support party. example, post-Soviet leaders' main prior experience initial bases support via (prior) dominant party – .e. Soviet Union – even though either leader left party disbanded regime took power. many leaders selected elections even though dictatorship ruling party.

title: Autocratic Regime Features, Version 1.0 — gwf
text: data set codes history regime support political parties (partyhistory): noparty support party postseizure_party created seizure power priorelection prior party, created support autocratic leader's election initiation dictatorship (e.g., Fujimori Peru) priornosupport prior party, never won 10 percent electoral support priorwinsupport prior party, won support prior autocracy insurgent insurgent/rebel party initiation dictatorship priordem prior party won 10 percent support prior democracy another variable codes military leader's relationship parties (militparty). variable captures whether regime leader military – .e., regime leader active duty retired military/security officer (NCO) prior accession power – created political party support regime. variable, derive following variables: noparty regime leader's supporters organized party ally_regime leader allies pre-existing party accession power. difference ally priorparty (see ) dictator allied old party assuming office priorparty, assuming office ally. newparty regime leader close ally creates party support regime accession office priorparty regime leader's supporters organized party prior accession power, party now supports regime large overlap militparty_newparty partyhistory_postseizure overlap perfect latter refers party former refers behavior leader leader's main prior experience military. example Torrijos regime Panama (1968-1982) illustrates . decade power Torrijos created new party 1978 (coded starting January 1, 1979). Thus militparty_newparty partyhistory_postseizure coded 1 starting 1979. However, Torrijos died 1981 Flores succeeded (coded new leader starting 1982). partyhistory_postseizure variable still coded 1 1982 Flores kept support party created post-seizure power (.e. post-1968 regime seized power). militparty_newparty coded 0 1982 Flores create new party; behavior second regime leader (Flores) different first (Torrijos) insofar first created new support party second instead used support party inherited predecessor. cases, partyhistory_postseizure coded 1, militparty_newparty coded 0 militparty_priorparty coded 1. instances arise often first regime leader creates new support party regime seized power second regime leader retains support post-regime seizure party. regimes first leader comes power pre-existing party organized run office election just prior initiation dictatorship (e.g., Francois Duvalier Haiti Heydar Aliyev Azerbaijan) military officers just prior seizing power, one instance leader's primary prior experience high-ranking military officer (Jose Antonio Ramon Panama (1954-1955))

title: Autocratic Regime Features, Version 1.0 — gwf
text: definitions coding rules, detailed. definitions intended provide readers basic understanding type information contained raw data. ldr_group (categorical) identify regime leader achieved office /whose support put office: ldr_group_priordem: prior democratic election ldr_group_domparty: dominant party ldr_group_military: military junta ldr_group_insurgency: insurgency ldr_group_hereditary: traditional hereditary succession ldr_group_civsucc: civilian autocratic succession ldr_group_other: (interim, clerical). one interim autocratic leader, Monje Gutierrez (Bolivia 1947), one clerical regime, Iran 1979–NA. category captures situations : incumbent discarded marginalized initial supporters within year (demonstrating depend support); one faction ruling group eliminates marginalizes others; groups involved regime changing; father son (close relative) transition regimes lack rules hereditary succession. ldr_group_foreign: foreigners played dominant role choosing incumbent seizure (categorical) regime obtained power: seizure_family: seizure armed family seizure_coup: military coup seizure_rebel: insurgency/rebels seizure_uprising: popular uprising seizure_election: election seizure_succession: authoritarian incumbent rule change alter composition ruling coalition seizure_foreign: foreign imposed ldr_exp (categorical) regime leader's important career experience likely developed useful support network: ldr_exp_highrank: high-ranking military officer ldr_exp_lowrank: low-ranking military officer NCO ldr_exp_rebel: leader armed insurgency brought regime power title: Factor scores and IRT estimates of latent dimensions using the gwf data. — gwf_irt
text: gwf_country name country cowcode Correlates War country code. Countries  changed territory period 1946 2010 following country codes data set: Czechoslovakia (315); East Germany (265); Ethiopia (530); Eritrea (531); Russia Soviet Union (365); South Vietnam (817); South Yemen (680); Vietnam/North Vietnam (816); Yemen/ North Yemen (678); Yugoslavia/Serbia (435). Note regimes either lost (Ethiopia) gained territory (Vietnam/North Vietnam) lifetime regime country code throughout entire regime spell. Users note feature data set merging data sets. year calendar year pers_irt_11_F1 IRT scores personalism, 11 items pers_irt_11_F1 SE IRT scores personalism, 11 items pers_irt_10_F1 IRT scores personalism, 10 items pers_irt_10_F1 SE IRT scores personalism, 10 items pers_irt_8_F1 IRT scores personalism, 8 items pers_irt_8_F1 SE IRT scores personalism, 8 items pers_irt_11_full_info_F1 IRT scores personalism, full information, 11 items pers_irt_11_full_info_F1 SE IRT scores personalism, full information, 11 items party_irt_11_F1 IRT scores party, 11 items party_irt_11_F1 SE IRT scores party, 11 items military_irt_11_F1 IRT scores party, 11 items military_irt_11_F1 SE IRT scores party, 11 items party_factor Scores first factor factor analysis (party). military_factor Scores second factor factor analysis (military). personalism_factor Scores third factor factor analysis (personalism). fourth_factor Scores fourth factor factor analysis ().

title: Simplified dataset from Weeks 2014 — weeks
text: extended_country_name full name country. GWn Gleditsch-Ward country code. cown Correlates War numeric country code. ccode1 Alternative country code analysis. year year observation. abbrev1 Abbreviation country name. demjlw_2014_1 Binary indicator democratic regimes, based Weeks (2014) coding. juntajlw_2014_1 Binary indicator military junta regimes, based Weeks (2014) coding. strongmanjlw_2014_1 Binary indicator strongman regimes, based Weeks (2014) coding. machinejlw_2014_1 Binary indicator machine regimes, based Weeks (2014) coding. bossjlw_2014_1 Binary indicator boss regimes, based Weeks (2014) coding. regimejlw_2014_1 Categorical variable indicating regime type, based Weeks (2014) coding. militarygeddes_2014_1 Binary indicator military regimes, based Geddes, Wright, Frantz (2014). personalgeddes_2014_1 Binary indicator personalist regimes, based Geddes, Wright, Frantz (2014). in_GW_system Binary indicator whether country Gleditsch-Ward system year.
